Entry into Abu Dhabi requires a negative COVID test. Entry into neighbouring emirates does not require testing for entry. See news agency Al Arabiya website archived: https://english.alarabiya.net/en/coronavirus/2020/07/16/Coronavirus-Entering-Abu-Dhabi-now-requires-booking-appointment-for-a-COVID-19-test

UAE has launched a virtual doctor program to triage patients to the relevant health centres. They also publish COVID-19 information, awareness and videos on medical facts, myth busters and advice on preventing the spread of the virus. See ministry of health website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20201003144821/https://www.mohap.gov.ae/en/AwarenessCenter/Pages/COVID19-Information-Center.aspx

On 18 Sep the ministry of health announces new guidelines on social events which limit to 10 the number of attendees at weddings:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201004205829/https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/justice-safety-and-the-law/handling-the-covid-19-outbreak/guidelines-related-to-covid-19/safety-protocols-for-social-events

âThe re-opening of public schools has been postponed by two weeks in order to test all administrative, technical and teaching staff for coronavirus (COVID-19), the Ministry of Education has said.â âPublic schools were scheduled to re-open for the administrative, technical and teaching staff on September 6, but following the postponement decision, they will start the new academic year on September 20.â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913210132/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4371

âMost dine-in restaurants, public parks, movie theaters, public water parks, and other entertainment centers are closed until further notice.â However, âon September 3, restaurants and cafes were permitted to resume outdoor service with mandatory health precautions.â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913202426/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No recent policy changes regarding the size of private gatherings. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913202426/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Bahrain continues to operate its drive-through coronavirus testing centre at the Bahrain International Exhibition and Convention Centre. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913205113/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/bahrain/covid-19-bahrain-delays-new-academic-year-for-public-schools-by-two-weeks-1.73726819

âUpdate [on September 7th] to information on visa on arrival and entry requirements ('Summary', 'Coronavirus' and 'Entry requirements' pages)â:  âEntry to Bahrain is open to UK nationals and visas on arrival have been reintroduced for 68 nationalities including the UK. If you are eligible for entry, you will be required to undergo and pay for the enhanced arrivals testing procedure for COVID-19 and need to self-quarantine until test results have been received. Any person staying in Bahrain for 10 days or more must repeat the testing procedure on the 10th day following their arrival in the Kingdom.â   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913203940/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bahrain

Bahrain begins COVID-19 testing for all public school teachers, administrators. In order to ensure the safety of students before the start of the new academic year, the Ministry began randomly selecting students to conduct an examination according to the precautionary measures to combat Coronavirus (COVID-19). Sources  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928154541/https://www.bna.bh/en/BahrainbeginsCOVID19testingforallpublicschoolteachersadministrators.aspx?cms=q8FmFJgiscL2fwIzON1%2BDhHPsGgvvDZbH%2FaGSb5EHRo%3D  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928154659/https://www.gulf-insider.com/bahrain-students-randomly-selected-for-covid-19-testing/

The Bahraini government has decided to pay electricity and water bills on behalf of all citizens.  The move covers for all Bahrainis in their first residence for three months, beginning October with the amount not exceeding the bills for the same period last year for each subscriber. Source:    http://web.archive.org/web/20200928145132/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/bahrain/covid-19-bahrainis-exempted-from-power-water-bills-for-3-months-1.73868136

Dr Fawaz Al Sheroogui, Public Relations and Media Director of the Ministry of Education, said that students would start the new school year on September 16. The administrative and teaching staff of schools across Bahrain will start work on September 6. (all the later postponement only apply to public schools). Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928112025/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/bahrain/bahrain-to-start-school-year-on-september-6-1.73261452

HRH the Crown Prince decided to postpone the return of administrative, technical and teaching staff at public schools for a 2-week period until 4 October 2020, whilst ensuring that teachers and educational staff are periodically tested for COVID-19 in coordination with the Ministry of Health.    The Government Executive Committee also decided to extend the postponement of the return to in-person learning at public schools until 11 October 2020. This decision does not extend to private schools and their kindergartens, in accordance with measures already in place. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928111325/http://www.crownprince.bh/en/media-centre/news/8900/2020/9/17/Government-Executive-Committee-postpones-reopening-of-indoor-dining-services-and-return-to-in-person-learning-at-public-schools

The Government Executive Committee made the decision to postpone the reopening of indoor dining services at restaurants and cafes, for a period of one month until 24 October 2020.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928111325/http://www.crownprince.bh/en/media-centre/news/8900/2020/9/17/Government-Executive-Committee-postpones-reopening-of-indoor-dining-services-and-return-to-in-person-learning-at-public-schools

The Government Executive Committee, based on the recommendations of the National Medical Task Force, called on citizens and residents to limit gatherings to members of the same household and close social circle for a duration of 2 weeks until 1 October 2020 and comply with all precautionary health measures, which require a firm commitment to wearing masks in public settings and limiting outings to necessities, while strictly observing social distancing measures.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928111325/http://www.crownprince.bh/en/media-centre/news/8900/2020/9/17/Government-Executive-Committee-postpones-reopening-of-indoor-dining-services-and-return-to-in-person-learning-at-public-schools

The Government Executive Committee requires a firm commitment to limiting outings to necessities, while strictly observing social distancing measures, citing the next two weeks (till 1 Oct) as a crucial period. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928111325/http://www.crownprince.bh/en/media-centre/news/8900/2020/9/17/Government-Executive-Committee-postpones-reopening-of-indoor-dining-services-and-return-to-in-person-learning-at-public-schools

Following the central bank's requirement, it is reported that Bahrain banks confirmed to defer loan payments until the end of the year, as a continuation of the economic stimulus announced under the directives of His Majesty King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa -- Finance and National Economy Minister Shaikh Salman bin Khalifa Al Khalifa has said. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928150637/https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/economy/story/Bahrain_loan_payment_deferment_part_of_stimulus_Minister-SNG_185116378/

Now COVID-19 test certificate is available through the BeAware App. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928155658/https://www.gulf-insider.com/bahrain-covid-19-test-certificates-made-available-via-beaware-app/
Ongoing comprehensive tracing.

In-person classes for elementary and middle school students at the U.S. Navy base in Bahrain will resume on Sept. 27, 2020, after base leaders eased the health protection condition earlier this month.   Bahraini authorities recently decided to postpone allowing indoor dining at restaurants until Oct. 24 and delay in-person classes at public schools until Oct. 11. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200928105454/https://www.stripes.com/news/middle-east/navy-base-school-in-bahrain-to-reopen-classrooms-despite-teachers-union-objections-1.646129

Conflicting reports regarding inter-provincial travel in curfew areas. US Embassy in Algeria maintains that domestic travel between provinces where curfews are in place is banned, however, the UK Foreign Office is advising that travel between provinces is 'now permitted' (unable to find exact date that this change occurred).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200910153722/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/algeria/coronavirus  ---  https://web.archive.org/web/20200910162436/https://dz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Restrictions still in place. According to the UK Foreign Office: "There is a nationwide ban on family gatherings of any kind, including marriages."   https://web.archive.org/web/20201001183658/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/algeria/coronavirus

According to the US embassy, regional restrictions remain in place with curfews: "A curfew is in effect in 29 of Algeriaâs 48 provinces, including in Algiers, where the curfew is from 11pm to 6am. The other provinces covered by the curfew are:  Boumerdes, Souk Ahras, Tissemsilt, Djelfa, Mascara, Oum El Bouaghi, Batna, Bouira, Relizane, Biskra, Khenchela, Mâsila, Chlef, Sidi Bel Abbes, MÃ©dÃ©a, Blida, Bordj Bou Arreridj, Tipaza, Ouargla, Bechar, Constantine, Oran, SÃ©tif, Annaba, Bejaia, Adrar, Laghouat, El Oued"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201001183752/https://dz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy found.
No change in policy found.
Egyptian President Abdel Fattah El-Sisi on 5 October 'urged local authorities to prepare for a coronavirus second wave as the new academic year' is to start on 17 October.    https://archive.vn/owGwD

There appear to be no new policies in place. According to the UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office:  "There are no country-wide restrictions in place on shops, restaurants, markets, beaches or most leisure activities" however, "Some measures are still in place in parts of Iran, including temporary closure of high risk businesses and shrines, and cancellation of some public events. While restrictions for COVID-19 have been gradually lifted since April, each province is able to introduce restrictions to respond to localised peaks in infections. This may include lockdown and restriction of movement, and may be introduced with little warning."  Red zones (high risk areas in the country)include Tehran, Qom, Mazandaran, East Azarbaijan, Isfahan, Yazd, Khorasan Razavi, North Khorasan, Semnan, Gilan, Zanjan, Qazvin, and Kerman provinces. Stricter restrictions appear to be in place in these areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200914122501/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20200914122558/https://ifpnews.com/irans-covid-19-cases-hit-400000-ministry

Again, no new policies. The UK Foreign Office maintains: "Large events such as concerts and sports matches remain either cancelled or held behind closed doors"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200914122501/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus

From 5th September, schools nationwide reopened (apart from in red zones where infection rates remain high)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924135007/https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/452046/Schools-set-to-open-Sept-5-amid-pandemic

According to the UK Foreign Office, there are no nationwide restrictions "in place on shops, restaurants, markets, beaches or most leisure activities" although "in practice, some restaurants, markets and shops remain closed or may have restrictions in place on the number of shoppers they will admit restrictions".    https://web.archive.org/web/20200924140210/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus

The UK Foreign Office maintains that "While restrictions for COVID-19 have been gradually lifted since April, each province is able to introduce restrictions to respond to localised peaks in infections. This may include lockdown and restriction of movement, and may be introduced with little warning.  There are reports of travel restrictions in several provinces, including to important tourism and pilgrimage areas" however no specific regional restrictions could be identified.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924140210/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus
There appears to be no update on Iran's income support policies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924141305/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Again, no major update to debt/contract relief policies, or any indication that they have come to an end.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200924141305/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No change found. Schools continue to resume activity after 7 months of closure.

Israel announced a 3 week national lockdown effective 18 September from 14:00 until 11 October 2020. Cities are colour coded red orange or yellow based on their rate of infection, and rules vary between these.    Closure of the education system, except for special education, boarding schools and additional exceptions as detailed in the legislation regarding special authority in dealing with the coronavirus. (Remote learning will be enabled as much as possible.)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001092512/https://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-lockdown-rules-effective-from-september-18-at-2-p-m/     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001093334/https://www.timesofisrael.com/who-by-prayer-who-by-protest-a-guide-for-the-lockdown-perplexed/

Israel announced a 3 week national lockdown effective 18 September from 14:00 until 11 October 2020.     All but essential businesses are closed. Restaurants can operate takeaway services. In the public sector, the number of in-office workers will be reduced to 50 percent.  This does not apply to the private sector, which may continue operating under the existing health regulations, provided it does not offer in-person services or hold meetings with more than 10 people present

Israel announced a 3 week national lockdown effective 18 September from 14:00 until 11 October 2020.     Restrictions on protest- there are none according to the government decision released Thursday, but as residents are banned from travelling more than 1km and meeting in groups over 10 this effectively bans protests and public events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001092512/https://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-lockdown-rules-effective-from-september-18-at-2-p-m/     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001093334/https://www.timesofisrael.com/who-by-prayer-who-by-protest-a-guide-for-the-lockdown-perplexed/

Israel announced a 3 week national lockdown effective 18 September from 14:00 until 11 October 2020.     The regulations also generally cap indoor gatherings at 10 people, and 20 outdoors. There is a restriction of gatherings according to the color red in the âtraffic lightâ model â up to 10 people in a closed space and up to 20 in an open area. In areas that are not red: in closed structures, prayer shall be permitted in groups of up to 25 people.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001092512/https://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-lockdown-rules-effective-from-september-18-at-2-p-m/     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001093334/https://www.timesofisrael.com/who-by-prayer-who-by-protest-a-guide-for-the-lockdown-perplexed/

Israel announced a 3 week national lockdown effective 18 September from 14:00 until 11 October 2020.     The emergency regulations lay out health rules for public transportation, indicating it will operate during the lockdown, though it remains unclear whether it will be scaled back. Trains will cap capacity at 50%, and intra-city buses will be allowed to carry a maximum of 32 passengers. Intercity buses, meanwhile, may only take 30 passengers. Tickets for the trains must be purchased in advance, while bus tickets must be activated by the passengers, except for people who require assistance from the driver. Eating is not permitted on board.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001092512/https://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-lockdown-rules-effective-from-september-18-at-2-p-m/     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001093334/https://www.timesofisrael.com/who-by-prayer-who-by-protest-a-guide-for-the-lockdown-perplexed/

Movement in leaving oneâs home shall be restricted to 500 meters, other regulations stated this to be 1000m, causing confusion.  There is a long list of exceptions where people are permitted to leave home- including alternative medicine, or therapy; going to the Knesset; attending a protest; donating blood.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001092512/https://www.timesofisrael.com/israels-lockdown-rules-effective-from-september-18-at-2-p-m/     https://web.archive.org/web/20201001093334/https://www.timesofisrael.com/who-by-prayer-who-by-protest-a-guide-for-the-lockdown-perplexed/

International air travel divided into coloured groups based on infection rates.Green Location: isolation not required if you travel from a Green Location, as long as you did not stay in a Red Location during a 14-day period before your flight to Israel. Not all locations, even those designated Green by Israel, give Israelis entry clearance. Passengers must update regularly. Red Location: passengers who arrive in Israel from a Red Location will have to go into isolation.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200926230225/https://www.gov.il/en/Departments/DynamicCollectors/green-red-countries?skip=0

Article indicates that employees are furloughed from their jobs as government providing support, but unclear whether this support is always able to reach people in practice.    https://archive.vn/NY5Vw
Public Health Campaign Remains in place on the Ministry of Health Website    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001102543/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/corona/corona-virus-en/

Articles indicate that contact tracing is far from comprehensive in Israel    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001103241/https://www.timesofisrael.com/contact-tracing-failure-to-blame-for-severe-2nd-wave-outbreak-tv-report-says/

22 September    President Reuven Rivlin and Justice Minister Avi Nissenkorn announced Tuesday a special clemency process for fines aimed at helping those undergoing financial difficulties caused by the countryâs fight against the coronavirus pandemic.  The new process, drafted in a joint effort of the presidentâs office and the Justice Ministry, will apply to those who are in debt as a result of government restrictions meant to fight to the spread of coronavirus and who have previous outstanding debts.  Nissenkorn added, âIt is our duty to do everything we can to help those in arrears to keep their heads above water. The special process we are announcing today will give further relief to the many people in debt because of fines and will solve the financial difficulties they are in by using the right to grant pardons.â    https://web.archive.org/web/20201001112525/https://www.timesofisrael.com/government-to-cancel-fines-for-people-suffering-financially-from-covid-19/

01 October    Ministry of Health FAQ as of 01 October says âSince the number of tests is limited, it is not recommended that you get tested in the absence of symptoms, except in the cases detailed above (close contact of confirmed case)    https://web.archive.org/web/20200919232646/https://govextra.gov.il/ministry-of-health/corona/corona-virus-en/faq-corona-en/

On September 8, Jordan reopened its main airport after a six-month shutdown. Authorities have set out rules for incoming passengers depending on the epidemiological situation in their countries of provenance, with all travelers tested for the Covid-19 illness on arrival.     Countries are classified into three categories, red, yellow and green - depending on the epidemiological scale of the COVID-19 outbreak in each respective country:  - Passengers arriving from countries classified as green will not be sent to quarantine, provided their COVID-19 tests are negative;  - Those arriving from yellow-listed countries will be required institutional quarantine for seven days and then to home-quarantine for another seven days;  - Passengers from red-listed counties  will undergo the same quarantine period but would be required to wear tracking bracelets during their one-week home isolation.  - Travellers from countries not listed in any of the categories cannot currently visit Jordan.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20200909091639/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/jordan/coronavirus  https://www.arabnews.com/node/1728571/middle-east  https://www.france24.com/en/20200908-jordan-reopens-main-airport-after-six-month-shutdown  http://web.archive.org/web/20200909102221/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1729381/middle-east  https://www.visitjordan.gov.jo/Country-Categories.html (unable to archive)  https://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/travel/jordan-reopens-to-international-flights-what-you-need-to-know-before-travelling-there-1.1074949 (unable to archive)
After schools started reopening, they began to close again due to rise in cases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924210708/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN26D2EG
Restaurants, coffee shops and bars were also closed for two weeks, thereby closing some workplaces.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200924210708/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN26D2EG

The authorities imposed up to a one-year prison term for any one hosting a wedding or social or public gatherings where over 20 people are present.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924210708/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN26D2EG

I would say this is not a full on requirement any longer, but rather recommended as the government promised not to impose a second lockdown.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924210708/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN26D2EG

The Jordanian government is also implementing a package of enhanced restrictions between Thursday, September 17, and October 1. The measures include the closure of schools, places of worship, and markets during the two week period. Restaurants and cafes are only able to provide delivery and takeaway services. Punishments for those violating restrictions have also been increased.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210634/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/380606/jordan-authorities-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-september-17-update-35

The Jordanian government is also implementing a package of enhanced restrictions between Thursday, September 17, and October 1. The measures include the closure of schools, places of worship, and markets during the two week period. Restaurants and cafes are only able to provide delivery and takeaway services. Punishments for those violating restrictions have also been increased.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210634/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/380606/jordan-authorities-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-september-17-update-35
No policy change

"As per Defense Order No. 16, wedding parties, mournings, and social gatherings of all kinds exceeding twenty people are banned, according to Adaileh."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210306/https://menafn.com/1100814917/Jordan-Government-announces-Defense-Order-16-says-Adaileh      https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210111/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"The Government of Jordan has closed restaurants, public spaces, and most schools until at least October 1, 2020.  Religious services, including those at mosques and churches, are also suspended.  In addition, the Government of Jordan has implemented social distancing regulations and mandatory mask-wearing in business establishments, public transportation, and government facilities due to COVID-19.  Jordan restricts gatherings to 20 people.  Delivery services for food, public transportation, and health services remain available."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210111/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"On September 14, 2020, the Jordanian Government adjusted the curfew for economic establishments to 12 a.m. (midnight) and for individuals to 1 a.m., both ending at 6 a.m. the following morning."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210111/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210111/https://jo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Regularly scheduled flights from Amman's Queen Alia International Airport (AMM) resumed on September 8. Rules for incoming passengers depend on the epidemiological situation in their countries of origin, with a color-coded classification list regularly updated by the Transport Ministry. The latest list can be found here. A minimum of one week of self-isolation to a maximum of two weeks of quarantine may be required for arriving passengers. All travelers will be required to provide a negative COVID-19 test administered in the previous 72-hours prior to travel and will also be required to be tested on arrival."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004210634/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/380606/jordan-authorities-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-september-17-update-35    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004211102/https://www.visitjordan.gov.jo/Country-Categories.html

"The Jordanian government will impose a 24-hour curfew in the town of Al-Qasr (Karak province) from Friday, October 2, until October 9 due to a rise in coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases in the area. From 06:00 (local time) on Friday, only those with special permits from local authorities will be allowed to travel in and out of Al-Qasr until October 9. Similar restrictions are in effect in Baqaa Camp (Balqa province) and the Batrawi and New Zarqa areas of Zarqa province until October 8, as well as Ghor Al-Safi and Ghor Al-Mazra'a in Karak province until Sunday, October 4."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201004211724/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/385006/jordan-authorities-to-impose-full-curfew-restrictions-in-al-qasr-between-october-2-9-update-37
Public schools, universities, and colleges are planning for virtual learning throughout the fall.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201002063959/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Government offices and private businesses with more than 50 percent staff, banking, financial, and construction sectors, retail stores, shopping malls, public parks, restaurant takeout and dine-in services, hotels, resorts, gyms, salons, and tailors are open with physical distancing measures.    It is allowed to return to the workplace in government agencies and the private sector with a percentage of more than 50% of the workers at the headquarters.    Compliance with health requirements (Article 1).        https://web.archive.org/web/20200821012951/https://corona.e.gov.kw/Re-Open-PhaseIV-En.pdf

Many types of social gatherings, including weddings, receptions, and public and private diwaniyas, are banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201002063959/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Compliance with general health requirements (mentioned in Article 1). The driver and passengers must always wear masks. It is also forbidden to ride for those who do not wear a mask.  Disinfecting transportation vehicles regularly, focusing on surfaces that the passenger usually touches such as door handles, armrest, seat belt locking, and window controls.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200821012951/https://corona.e.gov.kw/Re-Open-PhaseIV-En.pdf

Kuwait International Airport is operating at 30 percent capacity. Passengers arriving must register with the Shlonik application prior to boarding the aircraft and must home quarantine for 14 days upon arrival in Kuwait. A random PCR test will be conducted on ten percent of passengers of each flight upon arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201002063959/https://kw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Ministry of Health is randomly testing citizens and residents daily as part of its measures to curb COVID-19. Detailed instructions will be sent to those selected for a COVID swab via text message. The testing is not mandatory.

According to the UK Foreign Office, 'On 8 September the Lebanese government amended the curfew hours that had previously been in place. Movement is now prohibited between 1am and 6am'  http://web.archive.org/web/20200921143606/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lebanon/coronavirus

On 28th September, Lebanese authorities said Monday they would introduce a new zonal approach to containing coronavirus as the number of cases climbed ever higher.   " Caretaker Prime Minister Hassan Diabâs media office said the ministerial committee to follow up on coronavirus agreed on introducing the "zonal system," also known as the "traffic light system," as a way to determine the containment measures to be implemented in different areas."  " In red areas where there is âhigh risk," or more than eight cases per 100,000 people over 14 days, residents will be required to stay at home and there will be a local lockdown.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201001102756/https://khazen.org/index.php/150-The%20News/8383-surge-in-covid-19-cases-sees-zonal-containment-trialed-in-lebanon

With the new coronavirus zonal system announced by Caretaker Prime Minister on the 28th of September, " Yellow areas where there are between four to eight new cases per 100,000 people over 14 days are considered âmoderate risk.â Intensive testing and contact tracing efforts are to be taken in those areas and not just targeted at contacts of cases."   However, there is no evidence yet that this actually happening on ground so H3 will still be coded as 1.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201001102756/https://khazen.org/index.php/150-The%20News/8383-surge-in-covid-19-cases-sees-zonal-containment-trialed-in-lebanon
http://web.archive.org/web/20201001095946/https://www.moph.gov.lb/en/Pages/2/24870/novel-coronavirus-2019-
Some schools will be opened later in the year. There is no change from the previous measures.

On 7th September 2020, schools were scheduled to reopen, but will now remain closed for at least two weeks. New measures include restrictions to circulation and a nightly curfew, authorities said.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200907163647/http://www.ansamed.info/ansamed/en/news/sections/generalnews/2020/09/07/coronavirus-morocco-lockdown-schools-closed-in-casablanca_91cfea9a-d742-47d4-80f9-59b365918eba.html

Government reopens borders to 67 visa-exempt countries with some restrictions. Citizens of those countries cleared to travel to Morocco without a visa will be allowed entry, provided that they have an express invitation from a Morocco company or a confirmed hotel reservation.(MSN News, 14.09.2020).    All travellers planning to fly to Morocco must have valid negative Covid-19 test results issued no more than 48 hours before their flight.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925052707/https://travelbans.org/africa/morocco/
Currently schools are still closed. There has been no change in the measures.
Policies remain the same.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200921113408/https://www.timesofoman.com/article/minister-reviews-preparations-to-tackle-coronavirus-in-dhofar
Policies remain the same.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200921113408/https://www.timesofoman.com/article/minister-reviews-preparations-to-tackle-coronavirus-in-dhofar

The policy stays unchanged:    In East Jerusalem, on 6 September, residents of six Palestinians areas with high infection rates (Kafr Aqab, Beit Hanina, At Tur, Al Issawiya, Shuâfat Refugee Camp and Anata) were placed under a night curfew by the Israeli authorities, while some businesses were closed during the day too.     Since 18 September, all of East Jerusalem, including the localities above, has been subject to the comprehensive lockdown imposed on Israel, as highlighted above.     In Gaza's red areas (parts of Gaza city and all of Northern Gaza) a full lockdown remains in place. Since 18 September, malls in âyellowâ and âgreenâ areas reopened, and most shops are allowed to operate three days a week, provided that they abide by the required safety measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

As of 20 September, all children across the West Bank have returned to schools.    On 20 September, 420,000 students in grades 5 to 11 returned to schools across the West Bank (except East Jerusalem); grades 1 to 4 and grade 12 began the school year between 6 and 9 September. Since then, some 90 schools have been partially or fully shut down for periods ranging from one day to two weeks, following the detection of COVID-19 cases among students or school staff.     In East Jerusalem, on 6 September, residents of six Palestinians areas with high infection rates (Kafr Aqab, Beit Hanina, At Tur, Al Issawiya, Shuâfat Refugee Camp and Anata) were placed under a night curfew by the Israeli authorities, while some businesses and all educational institutions were closed during the day too.    After the MoH diagnosed the first cases of COVID-19 in the community in Gaza, the authorities closed all education facilities.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

The policy stays unchanged:    In East Jerusalem, on 6 September, residents of six Palestinians areas with high infection rates (Kafr Aqab, Beit Hanina, At Tur, Al Issawiya, Shuâfat Refugee Camp and Anata) were placed under a night curfew by the Israeli authorities, while some businesses were closed during the day too.     Since 18 September, all of East Jerusalem, including the localities above, has been subject to the comprehensive lockdown imposed on Israel, as highlighted above.     In Gaza's red areas (parts of Gaza city and all of Northern Gaza) a full lockdown remains in place. Since 18 September, malls in âyellowâ and âgreenâ areas reopened, and most shops are allowed to operate three days a week, provided that they abide by the required safety measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

In Gaza, as part of the lockdown imposed since late August, travel between governorates remains largely prohibited.     However, movement in the less affected areas within individual governorates, designated as âgreenâ and âyellowâ, is allowed between 07:00 and 20:00.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

For locals and humanitarian staff only, not applicable to international travellers:     The quarantine period for Palestinians returning to Gaza via the Israeli or Egyptian controlled crossings has been reduced from 21 to 14 days. Humanitarian staff entering Gaza are required to submit to only five days of quarantine, provided they can prove that they have tested negative in the 48-hour period prior to their arrival and after they have completed the five-day quarantine requirement and have a second negative test.    The Barrier crossings controlling the movement of tens of thousands of Palestinian workers between the West Bank and Israel, reopened on 21 September, following a three-day closure due to a Jewish holiday, despite the ongoing lockdown. Those returning to the West Bank are not requested by the Palestinian authorities to stay in quarantine or perform a COVID-19 test.    According to the UK foreign travel advice:    Foreign nationals are not permitted to enter unless they are citizens or residents of Israel. It is nearly impossible to enter the occupied Palestinian territory without entering Israel or Jordan first. Currently, the land crossing between Jordan and the Occupied Palestinian Territories is currently closed except in very limited circumstances.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201007222522/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/the-occupied-palestinian-territories    http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

The Hebron district, which has been the epicentre of the pandemic, recorded a 46 per cent decline in active cases. This may be partially attributable to a decline in the number of tests performed in that area, following inconsistencies in the testing policy by the Ministry of Health (MoH), alongside an increasing tendency, particularly among the asymptomatic, to avoid testing due to the social stigma associated with infection. By contrast, the number of active cases in East Jerusalem and in the Nablus governorate doubled, while in Ramallah it increase by nearly 50 per cent.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

The Hebron district, which has been the epicentre of the pandemic, recorded a 46 per cent decline in active cases. This may be partially attributable to a decline in the number of tests performed in that area, following inconsistencies in the testing policy by the Ministry of Health (MoH), alongside an increasing tendency, particularly among the asymptomatic, to avoid testing due to the social stigma associated with infection. By contrast, the number of active cases in East Jerusalem and in the Nablus governorate doubled, while in Ramallah it increase by nearly 50 per cent.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

In Gaza, contagion within the community remained of serious concerns, because of the low capacity of the health system. Health cluster partners continue to address key priorities, including to scale-up testing and contact tracing;    http://web.archive.org/web/20201007214447/https://www.ochaopt.org/content/covid-19-emergency-situation-report-18

Part two of phase four of Qatar's gradual lifting of COVID-19 restrictions has begun from September 15, 2020.  Gatherings  - Gatherings of 15 people indoors and 30 people outdoors  - Weddings with a maximum of 40 people indoors and 80 people outdoors  - All mosques open to perform daily and Friday prayers    Business and leisure  - Souks at 75% capacity  - 80% of employees allowed in public and private workplaces  - Wholesale markets at 50% capacity  - Cleaning and hospitality services in workplaces at 30% capacity and  resumption of home services  - Local exhibitions allowed at 30% capacity  - Malls at 50% capacity, with normal hours and children welcome  - Food courts in malls at 30% capacity  - Restaurants at 30% capacity and playgrounds and leisure centres remain closed  - Massage and sauna centres at 30% capacity  - Theatres and cinemas at 30% capacity for those 18 and older  - Museums and libraries at full capacity  - Continuing the suspension of home beauty, barber, massage and fitness training services    Transport  - Personal boat and yacht rentals at 30% capacity  - Metro and Bus at 30% capacity  - Driving schools at 50% capacity  - Continuing to follow Qatar's travel policy    Professional Sports and Personal Fitness  - Spectators at 20% capacity indoors and 30% outdoors  - Health clubs, gyms and pools at 30% capacity  - Continuing the closure of playgrounds and sports equipment in public parks      Education and Health  - Private healthcare facilities at 100% capacity  - Private education and training centres at 50% capacity  https://web.archive.org/web/20200917100234/https://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/16/09/2020/Part-two-of-phase-four-of-gradual-lifting-of-Covid-19-restrictions-begins
No change in police since Qatar started Part 2 of phase 4 of its gradual lifting of COVID-19 restrictions on 15 September.
No change in police since Qatar started Part 2 of phase 4 of its gradual lifting of COVID-19 restrictions on 15 September.

The Government of Saudi Arabia announced changes effective September 15 that allow holders of current residence permits (iqamas) with a valid entry/exit visa as well as holders of a valid business or visit visa to enter (including exit and re-enter) Saudi Arabia.  However, most land borders remain closed. The Government of Saudi Arabia has announced that the complete lifting of restrictions on entering and exiting the Kingdom and resumption of all means of transport through land, sea and airports will occur after January 1, 2021 and will be announced at least 30 days ahead of the opening.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200925062808/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Coronavirus: Saudi Arabia to lift ban on âumrahâ pilgrimage to Mecca The year-round umrah pilgrimage was suspended seven months ago because of the coronavirus pandemic Saudi Arabia will allow visitors from outside the kingdom to perform umrah from November 1. https://web.archive.org/web/20201001190247/https://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east/article/3102670/coronavirus-saudi-arabia-lift-ban-umrah-pilgrimage-mecca

On August 16, the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Education decided that all schooling will be virtual for the first seven weeks of the school year. The Ministry will reevaluate in October. https://web.archive.org/web/20200925062808/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Most commercial services and activities are currently available, though crowd size is limited to no more than 50. Grocery stores remain well stocked, and malls, shops, and private entities are open, though some may only offer limited services. https://web.archive.org/web/20200925062808/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

More than 3 million Syrian students started school in government-held areas Sunday, marking the first school day amid strict measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, state media reported.  Among the precautionary measures taken by the Ministry of Education were the sanitizing of all classrooms, walls, floors, stairs and bathrooms of schools, state news agency SANA said. Studentsâ temperatures will be checked as well.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200924120319/https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/syrias-schools-open-amid-anti-coronavirus-measures-72982448

"Recently, ad-hoc suspension of (...) some schools/classrooms where students or teachers were confirmed to have contracted COVID-19" has been reported.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

"The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced throughout May, albeit with some ongoing changes. (...) Public places, including markets, restaurants, cafes, gyms, parks, theaters, cinemas and most leisure facilities remain open, with mandated precautionary measures. Mosques and churches are open, with physical distancing requirements."    (Note: This indicator was coded as 2G because not all leisure facilities remain open)    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

Local authorities lifted the ban on mass gatherings, however, it seems that in cases relatively large gatherings occur mandated precautionary measures usually need to be followed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

Local authorities have lifted the ban on mass gatherings, however, "ad-hoc suspension of prayers in some locations well as closures of wedding halls(...)" has been reported recently.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

"Public and private transportation services have resumed (...)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

"The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced throughout May, albeit with some ongoing changes. The daily curfew remains lifted (...)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

The travel ban between and within governorates remains lifted.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

"As of 3 October, Syria and neighboring countries continue to reinforce precautionary measures at border crossings to limit the virusâs spread. Most land borders into Syria remain closed, with some limited exceptions from Jordan, Turkey and  Lebanon, including commercial cargo, relief shipments, and the movement of personnel from humanitarian and international organizations."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201007145248/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/finala_covid_response_update_no._11_.pdf

"Tunisia reopened its air, land, and sea borders on June 27, permitting entry to residents of certain countries based on a three-tiered classification of public-health risk (green, orange, and red). The most current lists can be found on ONMNEâs Facebook page."     https://web.archive.org/web/20200914180320/https://tn.usembassy.gov/message-for-us-citizens-08282020-2/    The countries included on the GREEN list updated recently : (As of Sep 24, 2020)    Orange List Entry Requirements  A negative PCR test no older than 72 hours from departure is required  A mandatory 14-day home or hotel quarantine is in effect, however;  Another PCR test can be done (at the travelers expense) between the 5th and 7th day of arrival, in order to lift quarantine order on day 7, instead of the full 14 days    Red category country citizens are banned from entering the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925070258/https://www.traveloffpath.com/tunisia-reopening-borders-to-tourists-starting-june-27/

Students take a class in a school in Tunis, Tunisia, Sept. 15, 2020. Schools in Tunisia reopened on Tuesday after a closure of six months due to the spread of COVID-19. The government required schools to take necessary measures to prevent the pandemic. More importantly, though, pupils will be attending school on alternate days to avoid breaching the limit of 18 pupils per class. The curriculum will be lightened but without relinquishing the basics. Holidays will be shortened.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007112542/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-09/15/c_139370619.htm    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007112602/https://blogs.worldbank.org/arabvoices/back-school-tunisia-amidst-covid-19

No measures as of now. However, the PM announced on Saturday 3rd October that Tunisian authorities will ban all gatherings and reduce working hours for employees in the public sector in order to stop the rapid spread of the coronavirus. There's no indication as to when this change will be implemented.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007113710/https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-10-03/tunisia-to-ban-gatherings-cut-public-sector-work-hours-due-to-pandemic    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007113719/https://www.thenational.ae/world/mena/tunisia-to-ban-gatherings-and-cut-public-sector-work-hours-due-to-pandemic-1.1087726

No restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007114252/https://tn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Tunisia reopened its air, land, and sea borders on June 27, permitting entry to residents of certain countries based on a three-tiered classification of public-health risk (green, orange, and red). Upon entry, travelers in one of the excepted categories listed above are required to present the results of a negative COVID-19 PCR lab analysis test administered within 72 hours of arrival. All red list arrivals from the excepted categories should expect to quarantine at one of the Tunisian Ministry of Health quarantine facilities for two weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201007114252/https://tn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
https://web.archive.org/web/20201007115525/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/tunisia/

"If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should call 190 (emergency services SAMU). They will ask a series of questions to assess whether it is likely that you have COVID-19. If COVID-19 is suspected, then they will arrange for someone to come to your home or hotel to conduct a test and they will advise you to self-isolate. COVID-19 PCR tests are only offered free if you are displaying symptoms. You can also pay for a test, if required for travel purposes, at the Institut Pasteur."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806161617/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tunisia/coronavirus
